images.title: Nearly 100 students and staff members at the University of South Dakota have reportedly tested positive for the novel coronavirus, according to data the school released Wednesday.
Morningside College marketing and communications vice president Carly Hanson and bookstore director Jodi Strohbeen model some of the school's logo face masks.
Dakota Valley Middle School sixth grader Seth Reinhardt has a face mask with the number 64 on it. That's the number he plays as a member of the DV Panthers Middle School football team.
Dakota Valley Middle School secretaries Deb Dailey and Madelyn Vander Weil turn models for a day, showing off some of the DV Panthers' most stylish face masks.
Dakota Valley School District Superintendent Dr. Jerry Rasmussen wears one of his school's masks inside the middle school gymnasium.
The South Sioux City School District provides their students with special Cardinals masks, according to Lance Swanson, director of communications and foundation.
The South Sioux City School District provides their students with special Cardinals masks, according to Lance Swanson, director of communications and foundation.
Karisa Meier, a theater education senior from Badger, Iowa, models a Northwestern College mask.
Briar Cliff University has both plain face masks as well as ones with the school logo on it.
Briar Cliff University has a selection of plain face masks as well as several with the school logo.
East High School is selling Black Raiders face mask as part of a fundraiser for the school's band program.

Hailey Hartman, a Buena Vista University junior from Storm Lake (front), joins fellow BVU Orientation Team members Taylor Caves (back left), a sophomore from Eddyville, Iowa, and Taylor Wedemeyer, a sophomore from Clarinda, Iowa, in showing off the facemasks they wear as the BVU Orientation Team works with incoming freshmen and transfer students on the campus of BVU in Storm Lake.

Hailey Hartman, a Buena Vista University junior from Storm Lake, shows off the BVU Orientation Team mask on campus on Thursday. Behind Hartman is the BVU Marching Blue, the marching band that began practice on campus this week.

Buena Vista University Orientation Team co-directors McKenzie Lansing, left, and Michael Demers sport their official BVU Orientation Team masks prior to Welcome Week events as freshmen and transfer students report to the BVU campus in Storm Lake, Iowa.
Western Iowa Tech Community College admission office's Josie Scott models one of WITCC face masks.

Dr. John Flannery, president of Bishop Heelan Catholic Schools in Sioux City, wears a face mask with the Heelan logo on it in this photo. With mask requirements and recommendations in place for students and staff returning to school, many districts are making school logo masks available.

Dr. John Flanery, president of Bishop Heelan Catholic Schools in Sioux City, wears a face mask with the Heelan logo on it in this photo. With mask requirements and recommendations in place for students and staff returning to school, many districts are making school logo masks available.

objects.author: Mason Dockter
objects.title: Several Siouxland colleges are dealing with COVID-19 infections
objects.html:
VERMILLION, S.D. -- Just after reopening their campuses for the fall semester, several Siouxland colleges are dealing with outbreaks of the novel coronavirus.

Ninety-four students and four staff members at the University of South Dakota have reportedly tested positive for the novel coronavirus, according to data the school released Wednesday. Another 406 people who may have been exposed to the virus are in quarantine.

Dordt University reported that nine early-arrival students had tested positive for the virus. The students are in isolation away from the campus in Sioux Center, Iowa.

Just down the road in Orange City, eight students and two employees at Northwestern College have tested positive since Aug. 17, a spokesman said Wednesday.

A student at Buena Vista University tested positive for the virus last weekend, a spokeswoman said Wednesday. The student is isolated at home. Individuals who were in close contact with this student were notified and asked to quarantine and monitor for symptoms.

Officials at Briar Cliff University last week confirmed a student had tested positive and was quarantined. A Briar Cliff spokeswoman on Wednesday said the university has no updates on cases there. The Sioux City school started its fall classes this week.
objects.text:
VERMILLION, S.D. -- Just after reopening their campuses for the fall semester, several Siouxland colleges are dealing with outbreaks of the novel coronavirus.
Ninety-four students and four staff members at the University of South Dakota have reportedly tested positive for the novel coronavirus, according to data the school released Wednesday. Another 406 people who may have been exposed to the virus are in quarantine.
Dordt University reported that nine early-arrival students had tested positive for the virus. The students are in isolation away from the campus in Sioux Center, Iowa.
Just down the road in Orange City, eight students and two employees at Northwestern College have tested positive since Aug. 17, a spokesman said Wednesday.
A student at Buena Vista University tested positive for the virus last weekend, a spokeswoman said Wednesday. The student is isolated at home. Individuals who were in close contact with this student were notified and asked to quarantine and monitor for symptoms.
Officials at Briar Cliff University last week confirmed a student had tested positive and was quarantined. A Briar Cliff spokeswoman on Wednesday said the university has no updates on cases there. The Sioux City school started its fall classes this week.
